title: Dufftown to Craigellachie and Aberlour Walk Route

images.title: Paul Collins / River Fiddich and sandy flood plain
images.caption: River Fiddich and sandy flood plain. Looking upstream towards Dufftown, note the wide sandy flood plain, photographed here during a rare dry spell in June.

images.title: Bridge over the River Fiddich by valenta, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Bridge over the River Fiddich

images.title: alan souter / Dufftown spur of the Speyside Way
images.caption: Dufftown spur of the Speyside Way. Taken at a cutting in the former railway line running along the river Fiddich valley. This track is a popular walk and cycleway.

images.title: John Brailsford / Craigellachie
images.caption: Craigellachie Woodland at end of Blue Hill with Craigellachie in hollow and Dandeleith on right edge

images.title: Craig Williams / Ben Rinnes and the river Spey
images.caption: Ben Rinnes and the river Spey. The tranquil river Spey pictured here in Summer near Craigellachie. Visible in the distance is the highest point in the local area - Ben Rinnes...

images.title: Iain Macaulay / River Spey
images.caption: River Spey at Alice Little Park in Aberlour.

description: This walk follows a popular section of the Speyside Way from Dufftown to Aberlour via Craigellachie. The walk runs for about 6 miles along a disused railway with lovely riverside and woodland sections along the way. You start off in Dufftown near the train station and head north along the River Fiddich to Craigellachie. The route then heads south west along the River Spey to finish in Aberlour. Here you can visit the Aberlour Distillery and the lovely Linn Falls which lies just south of the river.

details.subtitle: Pubs/Cafes
details.content: In Aberlour at the end of the route there's The Mash Tun for some post walk refreshments. It's in a great riverside location next to the pretty Alice Little Park. Built in 1896 as the Station Bar, you can now enjoy refreshments on the former station platform and enjoy the view of the old railway line running past the door, which is now the Speyside Way long distance trail. The pub includes a garden area with fine views over the fields and car parking. You can find them at postcode AB38 9QP for your sat navs. The pub is dog friendly.

display_address: Dufftown Road, Craigellachie, Moray, Alba / Scotland, AB55 4BN, United Kingdom
